definition[0]: a place where people stay in tents, shelters etc for a short time, usually in the mountains, a forest etc
note[0]: mining/logging etc camp (=a camp where people stay when they are doing these kinds of jobs)
example[0]: Let’s go back to camp – it’s getting dark.
example[1]: a camp near Lake Ellen Wilson
example[2]: The soldiers broke camp (=took down their tents etc) and left before dawn.
example[3]: We set up camp (=made the camping place ready) at nearby Icicle Lake.
example[4]: The expedition’s base camp (=main camp) was 6,000 feet below the summit.
example[5]: It was dark by the time we pitched camp.
definition[1]: a place where young people go to take part in activities, and where they usually stay for several days or weeks
note[2]: tennis/football etc camp (=a camp where you can do one particular activity)
example[6]: The camp offers hiking, fishing, canoeing, and boating.
example[8]: Two years ago, she started a summer camp for girls aged eight and older.
definition[2]: a group of people or organizations who have the same ideas or principles, especially in politics
example[9]: the extreme right-wing camp of the party
example[10]: At least Lynne is definitely in your camp (=supports you rather than someone else, and agrees with your ideas).
definition[3]: a permanent place where soldiers live or train
example[11]: Donny is stationed at Camp Pendleton.
example[12]: We made camp in a clearing in the woods.
example[13]: The soldiers set up camp outside the city.
example[14]: In the morning it was time to break camp.
definition[4]: to set up a tent or shelter and stay there for a short time
example[15]: We’ll camp by the river for the night, and move on tomorrow.
example[16]: camping gear such as a sleeping bag, tent, and backpack
definition[5]: a man who is camp moves or speaks in the way that people used to think was typical of homosexuals
definition[6]: clothes, decorations etc that are camp are very strange, bright, or unusual
